Highly efficient synthesis of imine activated by noble-metal-free CuInS2/C composite catalyst from MOFs under mild conditions Peng-Fei Guo Writing – original draft Investigation Conceptualization Le-Yan Li Investigation Hang Xu Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition ⁎ Bin Zhao Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Material Chemistry, Renewable Energy Conversion and Storage Center, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China Department of Chemistry Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Material Chemistry Renewable Energy Conversion and Storage Center Nankai University Tianjin 300071 China Department of Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Material Chemistry, Renewable Energy Conversion and Storage Center, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The self-coupling reaction of primary amines is an efficient method for obtaining imines, which are important components in the organic synthesis of medicines, pesticides, and fine chemical products. However, this reaction often requires the utilization of noble metals as catalysts to achieve high yields. Therefore, it is both desirable and challenging to explore efficient noble-metal-free catalysts. In this study, a composite catalyst of CuInS2/C with a regular octahedral shape and porous framework was synthesized using the HKUST-1 as precursor. The CuInS2/C catalyst exhibited effective catalytic activity in the self-coupling synthesis of imines under mild conditions, achieving a turnover frequency (TOF) of 105 h−1, which surpasses other non-noble metal catalysts. Mechanism investigations revealed that the excellent catalytic performance of CuInS2/C was attributed to its Cu(I) center and porous structure. The former generates radicals, while the latter enhances the transport of substrates and products, facilitating imine synthesis. Importantly, the CuInS2/C catalyst could be reused at least four times and applied in gram-scale experiments, demonstrating promising practical applications. This research presents a direct approach to developing noble-metal-free and highly efficient composite catalysts for imine synthesis using MOFs as precursors. Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Imine synthesis Economical catalyst Composite catalyst Data availability The data is available in Supplementary Material. 1 Introduction Imines are essential components in organic synthesis of medicines, pesticides, and fine chemical products [1–5]. The corresponding condensation synthesis of imine always needs unstable carbonyl compounds and dehydrating agents [6–8], leading to reactant deterioration and difficulty in purification. The self-coupling reaction of primary amines, as an alternative approach for imine synthesis, has attracted tremendous attention due to its stable feedstock and simplicity in purification. Various noble metal catalysts (e.g. Au, Ru, Pd, and Pt NPs) have been used for this reaction with high catalytic performance [9–15], but the high costs of those catalysts restrict their widely practical application. Non-noble metal substitution is a promising strategy to realize low-cost catalysts and large-scale production. Several Cu-based catalysts have been applied in imine synthesis, showing the unsatisfied catalytic performance with low yield, long-time consumption, and high reaction temperature [16,17]. Therefore, it is still necessary but challenging to explore efficient non-noble metal catalysts for imine synthesis under mild conditions. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) derivatives, which are prepared using MOFs as precursors, have shown the excellent application in the field of catalysis not only due to the benefits of uniform porous structures and large specific surface derived from MOFs, but also the excellent chemical stability [18–29]. According to previous studies [30–32], CuInS2, as a Cu-based catalyst, can generate radicals that facilitate the self-coupling synthesis of imines. Simultaneously, MOF derivatives with porous structures can enhance the transport of substrates and products, thereby improving catalytic performance. Thus, the combination of CuInS2 and MOF derivatives may overcome the above drawbacks and has the potential to significantly enhance catalytic efficiency and serve as promising candidate catalysts for imine synthesis. However, to our knowledge, no CuInS2/MOFs derivatives composite catalysts for imine synthesis have been reported so far. In this contribution, a composite catalyst of CuInS2/C was prepared using HKUST-1 (Cu3(BTC)2, BTC = benzenetricarboxylic acid) as a precursor, exhibiting a regular octahedron shape and porous structure. CuInS2/C catalyst could effectively catalyze self-coupling synthesis of imine under mild conditions, and the corresponding TOF value could reach 105 h−1 at 40 °C. The reaction temperature is lower than previous reports in thermal catalysis [4,12,17,33–37], and TOF value is superior to other noble metal free catalysts [4,17,34,35]. The mechanism investigations revealed that the highly catalytic performance of CuInS2/C could be attributed to its Cu(I) center and porous structure, which could respectively generate radicals and enhance transport of substrates and products to facilitate imine synthesis. Importantly, catalyst CuInS2/C could be applied in the gram-scale experiment and it could be also reused several times with a little decrease, providing the promising practical application in imine synthesis under mild conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials InCl3·4H2O (98 %, Le Yan), Thioacetamide (98 %, Le Yan), CuCl2·2H2O (99 % aladdin), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (98 %, Le Yan), Benzylamine (99 %, J&K Scientific), 4-fluorobenzylamine (98 %, Macklin), 4-chlorobenzylamine (98 %, Macklin), 2-chlorobenzylamine (98 %, Macklin), 3-chlorobenzylamine (97 %, Macklin), 4-bromobenzylamine (98 %, Macklin), 4-methylbenzylamine (98 %, Macklin), 4-methoxybenzylamine (98 %, Macklin), 1,2,3,4-Tetrahydroisoquinoline ((97 %, J&K Scientific)) Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 98 % DaMao) All chemicals were purchased without purification in this article. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Synthesis of HKUST-1: HKUST-1 was developed according to the previous literature [38], all of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (875 mg, 3.6 mmol), trimesic acid (420 mg, 2.0 mmol), H2O (12 mL), and ethanol (12 mL) were mixed together and stirred 10 min. Then, the mixture sealed in 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave, and then heated at a rate of 5 °C/min to 120 °C and maintain it for 12 h. After cooling down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/min, blue crystals were obtained through centrifugation and washed with ethanol for three times. The yield of HKUST-1 was about 61 % in ten batches. Synthesis of CuInS2/C: CuInS2/C was obtained according to previous work with slight modification [39]. The precursor HKUST-1 was calcined in argon atmosphere at 800 °C for 2 h to obtain metal carbon material, which was defined as a C supporter in the following investigations. 50 mL H2O were placed into 250 mL round-bottom flasks, the pH value of the solvent was adjusted to 2.5 with HCl, followed by addition C supporter (the calcined HKUST-1 100 mg), CuCl2·2H2O (0.375 mmol, 63.9 mg), InCl3·4H2O (1 mmol, 293.2 mg), and thioacetamide (2 mmol, 150 mg). The obtained mixture was placed in an oil bath at 80 °C for 6 h, and cooled down to room temperature. The black participate was obtained by centrifugation, washed with H2O for three times, and dried at 60 °C, resulting in the catalyst of CuInS2/C. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the catalyst was recorded by a Rigaku SmartLab X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was analyzed using an Axis Ultra DLD (KratosAnalyticalLtd.) spectrometer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on FEI Apreo S LoVac. Transmission electron microscopy was carried out on an FEI Talos F200X G2 Nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra was conducted in a 400 MHz Bruker 400 spectrometer. Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) was measured on Micromeritics APSP 2460 with N2 at 77 K. Gas chromatography (Agilent 8860) was employed with a flame ionization detector (FID). 2.4 Catalyst test Benzylamine (1 mmol), catalyst (25 mg), DMSO (1 mL), O2 (1 balloon) were put into the glass tube. The obtained mixture was placed in an oil bath at 40 °C for 8 h, and the temperature was cooled down to room temperature after reaction. A little of liquid product was diluted after reaction with an internal standard, and analyzed by GC equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). 3 Results and discussion CuInS2/C was prepared as illustrated in Fig. 1 a. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed, and the corresponding diffraction peaks were consistent with simulated wurtzite CuInS2 (Fig. 1b) [40,41], confirming the formation of wurtzite CuInS2. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of CuInS2/C sample was characterized. The peaks at 932.1 eV and 952.0 eV were attributed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 of Cu(I) (Fig. 1c) [42], and the signal peaks of 444.9 eV (In 3d5/2) and 452.3 eV (In 3d3/2) were ascribed to In(III) (Fig. 1d) [43]. Two obvious peaks at 161.4 eV and 162.6 eV were corresponded with Cu-S and In-S (Fig. S1d) [44]. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) indicated that the morphology of CuInS2/C still maintained octahedral structure of HKUST-1 crystals (Fig. 1f), and EDX Mapping also demonstrated that the elements of Cu, In, S were uniformly dispersed on the surface (Fig. S2). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) clearly exhibited CuInS2/C with 0.166 nm lattice spacing (Fig. 1g), attributing to (312) lattice plane of the CuInS2 on the surface of the catalyst [45]. The N2 adsorption isotherm of CuInS2/C was also performed to confirm its porous structure, exhibiting a type-III adsorption isotherm (Fig. S3a). Thus, the porous CuInS2/C with uniform active center can enhance transport of substrates and products, offering the promising application in the synthesis of imine. In order to explore the optimized reaction conditions of imine synthesis, the self-coupling reaction of benzylamine to synthesize N-benzylidenebenzylamine was selected as a model reaction under various conditions (Table 1 ). O2 was used as the oxidant for the following investigations. Almost no yield of N-benzylidenebenzylamine in the blank experiment (Table 1, Entry 1) revealed that catalyst was required to improve the catalytic efficiency in this system, and the yield of N-benzylidenebenzylamine was not obvious increased after removing catalyst via hot filtration experiments (Fig. S4b). Then, CuInS2/C (C, HKUST-1 pyrolysis temperature at 800 °C) was applied as the catalyst, and showed an excellent yield 91 %, (Table 1, Entry 2). The influence of C platform of pyrolysis temperature and its amount was also explored. 87 % and 89 % yield of N-benzylidenebenzylamine were found when the pyrolysis temperature was 700 °C and 900 °C, respectively (Table 1, Entries 3 and 4), indicating that 800 °C was the optimal pyrolysis temperature. The yields of N-benzylidenebenzylamine decreased to 66 % and 85 % respectively after halving/doubling the supporter (pyrolyzed HKUST-1) in the preparation of catalysts (Table 1, Entries 5, 6). Meanwhile, the yield decreased to 78 % using 15 mg catalyst (Table 1, Entry 7), and no obvious enhancement of yield could be observed using more catalyst (Table 1, Entry 8), suggesting that 25 mg should be the optimal amount of the catalyst. The reaction solvents were further explored, and 61 %, 62 %, 76 %, 72 %, 70 % and 58 % yield of product were obtained when the solvents were replaced with 1,4-dioxane (Diox), toluene (TOL), tetrahydrofuran (THF), ethyl acetate (EA), water (H2O) ethanol (EtOH) (Table 1, Entries 9–14). In terms of reaction time and temperature, 89 % yield of product was achieved at 7 h, and the 91 % yield was obtained after a reaction time prolonged to 9 h (Table 1, Entries 15 and 16). The yield decreased to 77 % as temperature decreased to 30 °C (Table 1, Entry 17), and no obvious enhancement of yield could be observed after further increasing the reaction temperature to 50 °C (Table 1, Entry 18). Based on the above results, the optimized reaction conditions should be 8 h and 40 °C in DMSO under O2 with 25 mg catalysts CuInS2/C derived from HKUST-1. To further investigate the universality of catalyst CuInS2/C, several typical substrates were employed under the optimized reaction conditions (Table 2 ). Halogen substituted benzylamines (4-fluorobenzylamine, 4-chlorobenzylamine, and 4-bromobenzylamine) were applied in this system. With the stronger electron-withdrawing groups substituted in benzylamine of F, Cl, and Br, the corresponding yields were 96 %, 90 %, and 92 % (Table 2, Entries 2–4), respectively, suggesting that the electron-withdrawing group possessed no obvious effect on this reaction. On the other hand, the electron-donating groups (CH3 and OCH3) substituted in benzylamines also showed no obvious effect on the yield (95 % and 96 %) (Table 2, Entries 5, 6). Thus, the yield was not affected by the substituent electron effect. Moreover, ortho/meta-Cl substituted benzylamines and tetrahydroisoquinoline were used as the substrates to explore the steric effect. The corresponding yields were 81 %, 80 %, and 87 %, respectively (Table 2, Entries 7–9). The steric hindrance could weaken the interaction between active center and the substrate, resulting in an inferior conversion efficiency. Thus, these results clearly revealed that CuInS2/C possessed high catalytic activity in imine synthesis with various substrates. To explore the reaction mechanism, several controlling experiments and 1H NMR monitoring were carried out. Only 13 % and 59 % yields were obtained using C and CuInS2 as catalysts, respectively (Table 1, Entries 19 and 20). The mixture of CuInS2 and C as the catalyst showed 74 % yield (Table 1, Entry 21), which was obvious lower than CuInS2/C as the catalyst (Table 1, Entry 2), possibly attributing to highly substance transport driven by its porous structure. The influence of precursors was also explored. Several classical frameworks of UIO-66, ZIF-67, Cu-BDC, MIL-68 (In) and commercial carbon were utilized as precursors to load CuInS2, and the corresponding yields of N-benzylidenebenzylamine were 51 %, 68 %, 63 %, 56 % and 69 %, respectively (Table 1, Entries 22–26), suggesting HKUST-1 was the optimal precursor among these MOFs. On the other hand, 1H NMR monitoring was used to further explore the mechanism of this reaction. The proton signal intensity of benzylamine at δ = 3.70 ppm was completely disappeared after adding CuInS2/C at 2 h, and the characteristic peaks of the corresponding products at δ = 8.51 ppm and 4.78 ppm gradually appeared and enhanced. (Fig. 2 a). Furthermore, two radicals of •O2 − and •OH were trapped by the DMPO (5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide) and detected by the Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) measurement (Fig. 2b). The formation of •O2 − and •OH radical may be attributed to Cu(I) catalysis and the H2O2 decomposition. Thus, both CuInS2 and porous structure play an important role in imine synthesis. On the basis of the above results and previous reports [46,47], a possible mechanism was proposed as below (Fig. 2c). First, an electron was received by O2 to form •O2 − on the surface of the catalyst, while Cu(I) was lost an electron to produce Cu (II). Then, Cu (II) received an electron from benzylamine to form Cu(I) and organic radical A. Second, organic radical A and •O2 − radical was directly reacted to form N-benzylideneamine and H2O2. Meanwhile, H2O2 simultaneously converted to •OH, which also could combine with organic radical A to generate N-benzylideneamine (B). Subsequently, three pathways were occurred in the following reaction, intermediate N-benzylideneamine (B) was further oxidized to produce benzaldehyde in the presence of O2. Another benzylamine molecule reacted with benzaldehyde to generate main product of N-benzylidenebenzylamine (pathway I). N-benzylideneamine (B) was combined with benzylamine to produce intermediate (C), which was further decomposed into N-benzylidenebenzylamine (pathway II), by-product of benzonitrile was obtained from the oxidation of N-benzylideneamine (B) (pathway III). In this catalytic system, benzaldehyde, •O2 − and •OH were detected, therefore the corresponding mechanism synthesis of N-benzylidenebenzylamine in this system tended to follow pathway I (Fig. 2 c). Regeneration and stability of catalysts in various heterogeneous system were an indispensable factor to estimate their catalytic property, and CuInS2/C catalyst could be simply separated and reused from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. Hence, the regeneration of CuInS2/C catalyst was further explored. As shown in (Fig. 3 ), the catalyst could be reused at least four times, and the evolution yields of the product with the increased reaction time displayed similar performance over the fresh and used catalyst (Fig. S4a), meanwhile, the diffraction peaks of the used catalyst in PXRD still matched with the fresh samples. The element’s valence state of Cu 2p and In 3d in utilized catalyst were still retained, only a little of the S element on the surface of the catalyst was oxidized after reaction (Fig. S5d). EDX mapping suggested that the elements of Cu, In, and S were still uniformly distributed on the surface of the utilized catalyst (Fig. S6). N2 adsorption–desorption experiment revealed that the used CuInS2/C could maintain its porous structure (Fig. S3a), and leakage amount of Cu and In were 0.17 % and 1.1 % after reaction. Thus, CuInS2/C catalyst showed good regeneration ability. In addition, the TOF of N-benzylidenebenzylamine could reach 105 h−1 under mild reaction conditions, which is superior to the reported non-noble metal catalysts (Table S1). Meanwhile, CuInS2/C catalyst also showed 90 % yield of product in gram-scale experiment (Table 1, Entry 27). Therefore, CuInS2/C catalyst could be applied as an excellent heterogeneous catalyst, showing the promising practical application in large-scale imine synthesis. 4 Conclusions In summary, we synthesized a composite catalyst of CuInS2/C with a regular octahedral shape using the HKUST-1 as precursor. CuInS2/C demonstrated effective and recyclable catalytic activity in the self-coupling synthesis of imines under mild conditions. The corresponding reaction temperature (40 °C) and turnover frequency (TOF) value (105 h−1) surpassed those of other non-noble metal catalysts in previous studies. Mechanism investigations suggested that the excellent catalytic performance of CuInS2/C was attributed not only to radicals triggered by the Cu(I) center but also to the efficient transport of substrates and products facilitated by its porous structure. Importantly, the CuInS2/C catalyst maintained its catalytic activity in regeneration tests and could be applied in gram-scale experiments, offering promising practical applications under mild conditions. Therefore, this study presents a simple approach to obtaining noble-metal-free and highly efficient composite catalysts for imine synthesis using MOFs as precursors, offering promising potential for sustainable and cost-effective catalysts development for other organic synthesis in the future. coredata.dc:description: The self-coupling reaction of primary amines is an efficient method for obtaining imines, which are important components in the organic synthesis of medicines, pesticides, and fine chemical products. However, this reaction often requires the utilization of noble metals as catalysts to achieve high yields. Therefore, it is both desirable and challenging to explore efficient noble-metal-free catalysts. In this study, a composite catalyst of CuInS2/C with a regular octahedral shape and porous framework was synthesized using the HKUST-1 as precursor. The CuInS2/C catalyst exhibited effective catalytic activity in the self-coupling synthesis of imines under mild conditions, achieving a turnover frequency (TOF) of 105 h−1, which surpasses other non-noble metal catalysts. Mechanism investigations revealed that the excellent catalytic performance of CuInS2/C was attributed to its Cu(I) center and porous structure. The former generates radicals, while the latter enhances the transport of substrates and products, facilitating imine synthesis. Importantly, the CuInS2/C catalyst could be reused at least four times and applied in gram-scale experiments, demonstrating promising practical applications. This research presents a direct approach to developing noble-metal-free and highly efficient composite catalysts for imine synthesis using MOFs as precursors.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient synthesis of imine activated by noble-metal-free CuInS2/C composite catalyst from MOFs under mild conditions
